322.question: After the defeat of the French in Canada, what were the French-speaking Catholic people known as?
322.note: The French speaking Catholic people, known as habitants or Canadiens, strove to preserve their way of life in the English-speaking, Protestant-ruled British Empire.

323.question: After World War I, the British Empire evolved into a free association of states known as
323.note: After the First World War, the British Empire evolved into a free association of states known as the British Commonwealth of Nations. Canada remains a leading member of the Commonwealth to this day, together with other successor states of the Empire such as India, Australia, New Zealand, and several African and Caribbean countries.

324.question: Anglophones are:

options.c: People who speak English as a first language
options.d: People who speak languages other than English

324.note: English and French are the two official languages and are important symbols of identity. English speakers (Anglophones) and French speakers (Francophones) have lived together in partnership and creative tension for more than 300 years.

325.question: Approximately how many Canadian soldiers served in the second World War?
325.note: More than one million Canadians and Newfoundlanders served in the Second World War, out of a population of 11.5 million.

326.question: Britain advocated interning Austro-Hungarian subjects as “enemy aliens” from during World War I
326.note: Regrettably, from 1914 to 1920, Ottawa interned over 8,000 former Austro-Hungarian subjects, mainly Ukrainian men, as “enemy aliens” in 24 labour camps across Canada, even though Britain advised against the policy.

327.question: British Columbia is known as Canada’s Pacific Gateway because:

options.a: Because it is on the Pacific Coast of Canada
options.b: Billions of dollars in products are shipped to and from Asia
options.c: Because most of its residents work in the fishing industry on the Pacific Ocean
options.d: Because there are many beaches along its Pacific coast

327.note: British Columbia is known for its majestic mountains and as Canada’s Pacific gateway. The Port of Vancouver, Canada’s largest and busiest, handles billions of dollars in goods traded around the world.

328.question: By the end of the Second World War, Canada had the largest navy in the world
328.note: Canada had the third largest navy in the world.

329.question: Canada contributed more to the Allied air effort than any other Commonwealth country
329.note: The Royal Canadian Air Force (RCAF) took part in the Battle of Britain and provided a high proportion of Commonwealth aircrew in bombers and fighter planes over Europe. Moreover, Canada contributed more to the Allied air effort than any other Commonwealth country, with over 130,000 Allied air crew trained in Canada under the British Commonwealth Air Training Plan.

330.question: Canada Day is on:
330.note: The Dominion of Canada was officially born on July 1, 1867. Until 1982, July 1 was celebrated as “Dominion Day” to commemorate the day that Canada became a self-governing Dominion. Today it is officially known as Canada Day.

331.question: Canada got its name from word Kanata which means?
331.note: Cartier heard two captured guides speak the Iroquoian word Kanata, meaning “village.” By the 1550s, the name of Canada began appearing on maps.

332.question: Chief Tecumseh aided British soldiers in the War of 1812
332.note: Canadian volunteers and First Nations, including Shawnee led by Chief Tecumseh, supported British soldiers in Canada’s defence.

333.question: Due to the effort of which Canadian, Quebec granted women the right to vote in 1940.
333.note: Due to the work of Thérèse Casgrain and others, Quebec granted women the vote in 1940.

334.question: How many Canadian soldiers served in World War I?
334.note: More than 600,000 Canadians served in the Great War, most of them volunteers, out of a total population of eight million.

335.question: In 1792, some black Nova Scotians left Canada to established the city of Freetown in what country?
335.note: In turn, in 1792, some black Nova Scotians, who were given poor land, moved on to establish Freetown, Sierra Leone (West Africa), a new British colony for freed slaves.

336.question: In 1814, who led an expedition from Nova Scotia that burned down the White House and other public buildings in Washington DC?
336.note: In retaliation in 1814, Major-General Robert Ross led an expedition from Nova Scotia that burned down the White House and other public buildings in Washington, D.C.

337.question: In the early days, what form of transportation did Aboriginal peoples and fur traders use?
337.note: In the early days, Aboriginal people and fur traders use the waterways as a form of transportation.

338.question: In what parts of Canada did the Aboriginal peoples first settle?

options.a: The North and the Great Lakes regions
options.b: The Great Lakes regions and the South

338.note: The ancestors of Aboriginal peoples are believed to have migrated from Asia many thousands of years ago. They first settled all over Canada.

339.question: Is current Canada – US border outcome of Second World War?
339.note: The present-day Canada-U.S.A. border is partly an outcome of the War of 1812, which ensured that Canada would remain independent of the United States.

340.question: Lord Durham recommended that Upper and Lower Canada should remain separate
340.note: Lord Durham, an English reformer sent to report on the rebellions, recommended that Upper and Lower Canada be merged and given responsible government.

341.question: Metis is the descendant of:

options.a: First Nations men and Acadians women
options.b: French or English women and First Nations Men
options.c: First Nations women and French or English traders

341.note: The Métis are a distinct people of mixed Aboriginal and European ancestry, the majority of whom live in the Prairie provinces. They come from both French- and English-speaking backgrounds and speak their own dialect, Michif.

342.question: Nunavut became a territory:
342.note: Nunavut, meaning “our land” in Inuktitut, was established in 1999 from the eastern part of the Northwest Territories, including all of the former District of Keewatin.

343.question: RCMP stands for
343.note: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) enforce federal laws throughout Canada and serve as the provincial police in all provinces and territories except Ontario and Quebec.

344.question: Responsibilities of the provincial government include:
344.note: Responsibilities of the Provincial and Territorial government include: Education, Health Care, Natural Resources, Highways, Policing (ON & Quebec), Property and Civil Rights, Immigration (shared), Agriculture (shared), Environment (shared)

345.question: The aboriginal peoples of Canada are:
345.note: The ancestors of Aboriginal peoples are believed to have migrated from Asia many thousands of years ago. They were the first inhabitants of Canada.

346.question: The battle of Vimy Ridge is important to Canadians because:

options.a: It was the last battle of the Second World War
options.b: It was the last battle of the First World War
options.c: It was the first victory of the First World War
options.d: It symbolized Canada as a nation

346.note: The Canadian Corps captured Vimy Ridge in April 1917. It is important to Canadians because it symbolizes Canada as a nation.

347.question: The early explorers first came to Atlantic Canada because they wanted to:

options.b: Settle there and attract more settlers
options.c: Fish and trade with First Nations people

347.note: The early explorers first came to Atlantic Canada to fish and trade with the First Nations people.

348.question: The first representative assembly was elected in what city in 1758?
348.note: Democratic institutions developed gradually and peacefully. The first representative assembly was elected in Halifax, Nova Scotia, in 1758.

349.question: The founding peoples of Canada are:
349.note: The three founding peoples of Canada are Aboriginal, French, and British.

350.question: The Hudson’s Bay Company adopted what animal as its symbol?
350.note: The beaver was adopted centuries ago as a symbol of the Hudson’s Bay Company.

351.question: The Hudson’s Bay Company controlled the northern lands of Canada for how many years?
351.note: In 1670, King Charles II of England granted the Hudson’s Bay Company exclusive trading rights over the watershed draining into Hudson Bay. The Hudson’s Bay Company controlled the northern lands of Canada for 200 years.

352.question: The representatives of the provinces who worked together to establish a new country are known as the Fathers of Confederation
352.note: From 1864 to 1867, representatives of Nova Scotia, New Brunswick and the Province of Canada, with British support, worked together to establish a new country. These men are known as the Fathers of Confederation.

353.question: The skilled and courageous men who travelled by canoe were called what?
353.note: The skilled and courageous men who travelled by canoe were called voyageurs and coureurs des bois, and formed strong alliances with First Nations.

354.question: The state of World War II and public opinion in BC led to the forcible relocation of Canadians of what ethnic origin?
354.note: Regrettably, the state of war and public opinion in B.C. led to the forcible relocation of Canadians of Japanese origin by the federal government and the sale of their property without compensation.

355.question: The United Empire Loyalists were:

options.a: The First Nations and the Inuits
options.c: Settlers from the United States at the time of the American Revolution

355.note: In 1776, the 13 British colonies to the south of Quebec declared independence and formed the United States. More than 40,000 people loyal to the Crown, called “Loyalists,” fled the oppression of the American Revolution to settle in Nova Scotia and Quebec.

356.question: To make immigration to Western Canada easier, the government:

options.c: Lowered the requirement for immigration to Western Canada

356.note: British Columbia joined Canada in 1871 after Ottawa promised to build a railway (Canadian Pacific Railway) to the West Coast to make transportation easier.

357.question: What Aboriginal tribe originally resided in the Great Lakes region?
357.note: The Huron-Wendat of the Great Lakes region, like the Iroquois, were farmers and hunters.

358.question: What act divided the Province of Quebec into Upper Canada and Lower Canada
358.note: The Constitutional Act of 1791 divided the Province of Quebec into Upper Canada (later Ontario), which was mainly Loyalist, Protestant and English-speaking, and Lower Canada (later Quebec), heavily Catholic and French-speaking.

359.question: What battle secured the Canadians’ reputation for valour as the “shock troops of the British Empire”?
359.note: The Canadian Corps captured Vimy Ridge in April 1917, with 10,000 killed or wounded, securing the Canadians’ reputation for valour as the “shock troops of the British Empire.”

360.question: What beach did Canadians storm and capture during the D-Day Invasion?
360.note: In the epic invasion of Normandy in northern France on June 6, 1944, known as D-Day, 15,000 Canadian troops stormed and captured Juno Beach from the German Army.

361.question: What British North American colony was first to attain full responsible government?
361.note: The first British North American colony to attain full responsible government was Nova Scotia in 1847–48. In 1848–49 the governor of United Canada, Lord Elgin, with encouragement from London, introduced responsible government.

362.question: What decade did the Great Depression occur?
362.note: The stock market crash of 1929, however, led to the Great Depression or the “Dirty Thirties.” Unemployment reached 27% in 1933 and many businesses were wiped out.

363.question: What did the Quebec Act of 1774 establish?

options.b: Allowed citizens to hold public office
options.c: Accommodated the principles of British institutions to the reality of the province

363.note: To better govern the French Roman Catholic majority, the British Parliament passed the Quebec Act of 1774. One of the constitutional foundations of Canada, the Quebec Act accommodated the principles of British institutions to the reality of the province.

364.question: What document legalized Confederation?

options.b: The Charter of Rights and Freedoms

364.note: The British North America Act, 1867 legalized Confederation.

365.question: What is Confederation?

options.a: Countries joined together to fight in World War I
options.b: Provinces joined together to become a new country
options.c: Countries joined together in the fight in World War II

376.question: What year did the Montreal Stock Exchange open?

377.question: What’s the name of the predecessor of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police?

378.question: When did Canada become a country?

382.question: When was the Canadian Pacific Railway completed?

383.question: Where did the first European settlers in Canada come from?
383.note: The first European settlers in Canada came from France. The French settlers first established communities on the St. Lawrence River in the early 1600s.

384.question: Which act defined the responsibilities of federal and provincial governments of Canada?
384.note: There are federal, provincial, territorial and municipal governments in Canada. The responsibilities of the federal and provincial governments were defined in 1867 in the British North America Act, now known as the Constitution Act, 1867.

387.question: Which industry did most early European settles work in?
387.note: The French and Aboriginal people collaborated in the vast fur-trade economy, driven by the demand for beaver pelts in Europe.

388.question: Which prime minister granted the women’s right to vote?

389.question: Which province is the last one to join Canada?

392.question: Who became the first French Canadian Prime Minister?

410.question: How many Canadians have been awarded the Victoria Cross?
